text: I think the blast radius of a poorly written memo is way bigger than most people think. If you are just shooting off a message in a Slack channel with 15 other people, and it's confusing, you didn't include information you should have included, there's going to be a bunch of back and forth. Whereas if you had just taken another look at it, those 15 people would be off to the races.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny emphasizes the importance of reviewing your own writing before sending it, noting that many people skip this step due to time constraints. Wes explains why taking time to review written communication is crucial for workplace efficiency. She argues that poorly written messages create much more downstream work and confusion than people realize, affecting multiple team members who must then engage in clarifying conversations.
text_ko: 부실하게 쓴 메모의 파급 반경(blast radius)은 대부분 사람들이 생각하는 것보다 훨씬 커요. 슬랙 채널(Slack channel)에서 15명 정도 있는 곳에 그냥 메시지를 툭 던졌는데 내용이 애매하거나 들어가야 할 정보를 빼먹었다면 확인이나 질문이 계속 오가게 돼요. 반면 한 번만 더 검토했더라면 그 15명은 바로 다음 단계로 넘어갔을 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得一份写得烂的备忘录(memo)造成的影响比大多数人想象的要大得多。如果你在一个有15个人的Slack频道里随便发个消息，写得乱七八糟的，该说的信息也没说清楚，那就会引起一大堆来回扯皮。但如果你当初多检查一遍，那15个人早就开始干活了。
text_es: Creo que el impacto de un memo mal redactado es mucho mayor de lo que la gente piensa. Si mandas un mensaje rápido en un canal de Slack con otras 15 personas, y está confuso, no incluiste información que debías haber puesto, va a haber un montón de idas y vueltas. Mientras que si le hubieras echado otro vistazo, esas 15 personas ya estarían trabajando a toda máquina.

text: MOO stands for Most Obvious Objection. A lot of times we're surprised by the questions that we get especially in meetings, we feel blindsided. When really, if you thought for even two minutes about what are obvious objections that I'm likely to get, you often immediately come up with what some of those things are. Are you going to be able to anticipate every single objection? No. But can you anticipate the obvious ones? Absolutely.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks Wes about her MOO framework after mentioning it briefly earlier. MOO stands for Most Obvious Objection, which is a preparation technique for presentations and meetings. Wes explains that people often feel caught off guard by questions or pushback in meetings, when they could have anticipated the most common objections with just a few minutes of preparation beforehand.
text_ko: MOO는 '가장 명백한 반대(Most Obvious Objection)'의 약자예요. 회의에서 특히 예상치 못한 질문을 받아 깜짝 놀라 당황할 때가 많죠. 그런데 사실 단 2분만이라도 내가 받을 만한 명백한 반대 의견들을 생각해 보면 금방 몇 가지가 떠오르는 경우가 많아요. 모든 이의를 다 예측할 수 있냐고요? 아니에요. 하지만 분명히 예상 가능한 건 충분히 대비할 수 있어요.
text_zh: MOO就是Most Obvious Objection的缩写，也就是最明显的反对意见。我们在开会的时候经常会被一些问题搞得措手不及，觉得很意外。但其实你要是花两分钟想想，我可能会遇到哪些明显的反对意见，往往马上就能想出来。你能预料到所有的反对意见吗？当然不可能。但是那些明显的，你绝对可以提前想到。
text_es: MOO significa Most Obvious Objection, o sea, la objeción más obvia. Muchas veces nos sorprenden las preguntas que recibimos, sobre todo en las juntas, y nos sentimos como que nos agarraron desprevenidos. Pero la verdad es que si te pones a pensar aunque sea dos minutos en cuáles son las objeciones obvias que seguramente me van a salir, casi siempre se te ocurren varias de una vez. ¿Vas a poder anticipar todas y cada una de las objeciones? No. ¿Pero puedes anticipar las obvias? Por supuesto que sí.

text: I have a framework called strategy, not self-expression. And so the idea here is that most of the time, by the time we are giving feedback to someone, we have been frustrated for a while. Then I would schedule a one-on-one with a coworker to tell them the feedback and it would inevitably turn into a venting session where I was in the name of sharing the impact of what they did would share all my frustrations.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks Wes for advice on giving feedback effectively. Wes introduces her 'strategy, not self-expression' framework for constructive feedback. She explains that people often wait until they're very frustrated before giving feedback, which leads to unproductive venting sessions rather than strategic conversations focused on behavior change. The framework emphasizes focusing on motivating the desired outcome rather than expressing all your built-up frustrations.
text_ko: 저는 '전략(strategy), 자기표현(self-expression)이 아니다'라는 프레임워크(framework)를 가지고 있어요. 요지는 대부분의 경우 누군가에게 피드백(feedback)을 줄 때쯤이면 이미 한동안 답답함과 불만이 쌓여 있다는 거예요. 그래서 동료와 일대일(one-on-one) 미팅을 잡아 피드백(feedback)을 전하면, 결국 '그들이 한 행동의 영향(impact)을 알려주겠다'는 명목으로 제가 쌓인 불만을 다 털어놓는 벤팅 세션(venting session)이 돼 버리곤 했어요.
text_zh: 我有个框架叫做策略性反馈，而不是情绪发泄。这个思路是什么呢？就是说大部分时候，等我们要给别人反馈的时候，其实心里早就憋了一肚子火了。然后我会约个一对一(one-on-one)，想着要跟同事说说这个反馈，结果到最后肯定变成了吐槽大会，打着"分享你的行为对我造成什么影响"的旗号，把我所有的不爽都倒出来了。
text_es: Tengo un marco de trabajo que llamo estrategia, no autoexpresión. Y la idea es que la mayoría de las veces, cuando ya vamos a darle feedback a alguien, llevamos un rato frustrados. Entonces yo programaba una reunión uno a uno con un compañero para darle el feedback y inevitablemente se convertía en una sesión de desahogo donde yo, con la excusa de compartir el impacto de lo que habían hecho, terminaba soltando todas mis frustraciones.

text: I have a framework called CEDAF. C-E-D-A-F. It's kind of like Cedar, but with an F at the end. The C is comprehension. So have I given this person that I'm delegating to everything that they need to understand what it is that I want them to do. E is excitement. Am I explaining this in a way that is making this as exciting as it could be? D is for de-risk. Am I de-risking any obvious risks from delegating this?
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks Wes about her advice for delegating effectively while maintaining high standards. Wes introduces her CEDAF framework for delegation, which provides a systematic approach to assigning work to others. She explains the first three components: ensuring the person understands what they need to do (comprehension), making the work engaging by explaining its importance (excitement), and identifying potential problems upfront (de-risk).
text_ko: CEDAF라는 프레임워크(framework)가 있어요. C-E-D-A-F. Cedar랑 비슷한데 끝에 F가 붙은 거예요. C는 이해(comprehension)이에요. 즉, 내가 위임(delegate)하려는 사람에게 내가 원하는 일이 무엇인지 이해하는 데 필요한 걸 다 줬는지 확인하는 거예요. E는 흥미(excitement)이에요. 이걸 가능한 한 흥미롭게 설명하고 있는지요. D는 리스크 제거(de-risk)이에요. 위임할 때 생길 수 있는 명백한 리스크들을 줄여주고 있는지요.
text_zh: 我有个框架叫CEDAF，C-E-D-A-F，有点像Cedar这个词，但最后加个F。C是理解度(comprehension)，就是说我有没有把这个被委派的人需要知道的所有信息都给到位了，让他们完全明白我要他们干什么。E是兴奋度(excitement)，我在解释的时候有没有把这事儿说得尽可能让人有干劲？D是去风险(de-risk)，就是我有没有把委派过程中那些明显的风险都提前化解掉？
text_es: Tengo un marco de trabajo que se llama CEDAF. C-E-D-A-F. Es como si dijeras "Cedar" en inglés, pero con una F al final. La C es de comprensión. O sea, ¿le he dado a la persona a la que le estoy delegando todo lo que necesita para entender qué es lo que quiero que haga? La E es de emoción. ¿Estoy explicando esto de una manera que lo haga tan emocionante como podría ser? La D es para eliminar riesgos (de-risk). ¿Estoy eliminando cualquier riesgo obvio de delegar esto?

text: One of the most common myths about managing up that I definitely felt early on in my career was that I would have to manage up if I were more junior, but eventually I would outgrow it, that I would get senior enough that I would no longer have to do it. And it was a rude awakening that no matter how senior I got, managing up, I not only had to manage up, it actually became more important.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks why managing up is important and why people might underappreciate this skill. Wes dispels a common misconception about managing up - that it's only necessary for junior employees. She explains that she initially believed she would eventually become senior enough to not need this skill, but discovered the opposite was true. Managing up becomes increasingly important as you advance in your career because senior roles involve more ambiguity and strategic decision-making.
text_ko: 커리어 초반에 제가 분명히 느꼈던 상사 관리(managing up)에 대한 가장 흔한 오해 중 하나는, 주니어일 때만 상사 관리를 해야 하고 결국 시니어가 되면 더는 그걸 안 해도 될 거라는 생각이었어요. 그런데 막상 시니어가 돼도 상사 관리는 계속해야 하는 일이었고, 오히려 더 중요해졌다는 뼈저린 깨달음을 얻었어요.
text_zh: 我刚入职场的时候特别相信一个关于向上管理(managing up)的错误想法，就是觉得只有junior的时候才需要向上管理，等我做到高级别了，就不用再搞这套了。结果现实给了我当头一棒——不管我升到多高的位置，向上管理不但还得做，而且变得更加重要了。
text_es: Uno de los mitos más comunes sobre el "managing up" que definitivamente yo sentí al principio de mi carrera era que tendría que hacerlo siendo más junior, pero que eventualmente lo superaría, que llegaría a ser lo suficientemente senior como para ya no tener que hacerlo. Y fue una revelación dura darme cuenta de que sin importar qué tan senior me volviera, no solo tenía que seguir haciendo "managing up", sino que en realidad se volvía más importante.

text: I find that people tend to naturally be on the spectrum a little bit too confident as a baseline or not confident enough. So people who are too confident might state hypotheses as if they are fact. So I'm a big proponent of speaking accurately. You can avoid a lot of problems if you speak accurately about your level of conviction and about the actual amount of evidence that you have for something.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks about finding the right level of confidence when presenting ideas or recommendations to leaders. Wes explains that people typically fall into two camps: being overconfident or underconfident in their communication. She emphasizes the importance of 'speaking accurately' - being precise about your level of certainty and the evidence supporting your statements rather than presenting hunches as established facts or being overly self-deprecating about solid recommendations.
text_ko: 사람들은 보통 기본적으로 약간 과하게 자신감이 있거나, 반대로 자신감이 부족한 쪽으로 치우치는 경향이 있어요. 너무 자신감 있는 사람들은 가설을 마치 사실인 양 말해버리기도 해요. 그래서 저는 말을 정확하게 하는 걸 강력히 권해요. 자신의 확신 수준(level of conviction)과 그것을 뒷받침하는 실제 증거의 양(amount of evidence)을 솔직하고 정확하게 표현하면 많은 문제를 피할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我发现大家天生都有点偏向两个极端——要么就是太自信了，要么就是信心不足。那些过于自信的人经常把假设当成事实来说。所以我特别推崇准确表达这件事。如果你能准确地说出自己有多大把握，以及你手头到底有多少证据支撑，就能避免很多麻烦。
text_es: Me he dado cuenta de que la gente por lo general tiende a estar en uno de dos extremos: o se sienten demasiado seguros de sí mismos por defecto, o no tienen suficiente confianza. Los que son demasiado confiados suelen presentar hipótesis como si fueran hechos comprobados. Por eso soy un gran defensor de hablar con precisión. Puedes evitarte muchos problemas si hablas con claridad sobre qué tan convencido estás realmente de algo y sobre la cantidad real de evidencia que tienes para respaldarlo.
